abstract_summ: The S protein is densely decorated with N-linked glycans protruding from the trimer surface that affect S protein folding, processing by host cell proteases and the elicitation of humoral immune response.Biochemical, biophysical, and structural (cryo-EM) characterization of the SARS-CoV-2 S proteins produced in both cell lines demonstrate that the reported purification strategy yields high quality S protein (non-aggregated, uniform material with appropriate biochemical and biophysical properties).The recent comparative genomic studies highlight the insertion of Furin protease site in the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein alerting possible modification in the viral spike protein and its eventual entry to host cell and presence of Furin site implicated to virulence.Therefore, to explore conserved features in spike protein dynamics and to identify potentially novel regions for drugging, we measured spike protein variability derived from 791 viral genomes and studied its properties by molecular dynamics (MD) simulation.We validate the ability of our pipeline to identify protein stabilization mutants through known prefusion spike protein mutants.
title_summ: Distinct Structural Flexibility within SARS-CoV-2 Spike Protein Reveals Potential Therapeutic TargetsCharacterization of the SARS-CoV-2 Spike in an Early Prefusion ConformationIn situ structural analysis of SARS-CoV-2 spike reveals flexibility mediated by three hingesStructures, conformations and distributions of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimers on intact virionsSpike protein fusion loop controls SARS-CoV-2 fusogenicity and infectivityStructural interactions between pandemic SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein and human Furin proteaseMap of SARS-CoV-2 spike epitopes not shielded by glycansPrefusion spike protein stabilization through computational mutagenesisDynamical asymmetry exposes 2019-nCoV prefusion spikeExploring Conformational Transition of 2019 Novel Coronavirus Spike Glycoprotein Between Its Closed and Open States Using Molecular Dynamics SimulationsA thermostable, closed, SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimerDeciphering the Protein Motion of S1 Subunit in SARS-CoV-2 Spike Glycoprotein Through Integrated Computational MethodsStructure-based Design of Prefusion-stabilized SARS-CoV-2 SpikesStructural features of coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 spike protein: Targets for vaccinationStructure of mouse coronavirus spike protein complexed with receptor reveals mechanism for viral entryTargeting the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein prefusion conformation: virtual screening and molecular dynamics simulations applied to the identification of potential fusion inhibitorsHighly Conserved Homotrimer Cavity Formed by the SARS-CoV-2 Spike Glycoprotein: A Novel Binding SiteCharacterization of the SARS-CoV-2 S Protein: Biophysical, Biochemical, Structural, and Antigenic AnalysisClosing coronavirus spike glycoproteins by structure-guided designDistinct conformational states of SARS-CoV-2 spike proteinControlling the SARS-CoV-2 Spike Glycoprotein ConformationA possible strategy to fight COVID-19: Interfering with spike glycoprotein trimerization
title_abstract_phrases: Biochemical, biophysical, and structural (cryo-EM) characterization of the SARS-CoV-2 S proteins produced in both cell lines demonstrate that the reported purification strategy yields high quality S protein (non-aggregated, uniform material with appropriate biochemical and biophysical properties).The S protein is densely decorated with N-linked glycans protruding from the trimer surface that affect S protein folding, processing by host cell proteases and the elicitation of humoral immune response.The large scale tomography data set of SARS-CoV-2 used for this study is therefore sufficient to resolve structural features to below 5 Ångstrom, and is publicly available at EMPIAR-10453.Structures, conformations and distributions of SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimers on intact virionsSevere acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) virions are surrounded by a lipid bilayer from which spike (S) protein trimers protrude.The recent comparative genomic studies highlight the insertion of Furin protease site in the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoprotein alerting possible modification in the viral spike protein and its eventual entry to host cell and presence of Furin site implicated to virulence.Collectively, we establish an array of metrics for ensuring the production of high-quality S protein to support clinical, biological, biochemical, structural and mechanistic studies to combat the global pandemic caused by SARS-CoV-2.Closing coronavirus spike glycoproteins by structure-guided designThe recent spillover of SARS-CoV-2 in the human population resulted in the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic which has already caused 4.9 million infections and more than 326,000 fatalities.
